questions.question: A 25-year-old asymptomatic patient undergoes a routine lumbar spine X-ray for an unrelated complaint. The radiologist notices an incidental finding on the image. Which of the following findings would be inconsistent with spina bifida occulta?

A 28-year-old pregnant woman at 20 weeks of gestation undergoes a routine ultrasound, which reveals a fluid-filled sac at the lower back of the fetus. Which statement about myelomeningocele is most accurate?

options.A: Protrusion of meninges through a vertebral defect
options.B: Sac contains cerebrospinal fluid but no neural elements.
options.C: Better prognosis than other spina bifida types
options.D: Includes spinal cord tissue within the protruding sac.

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Includes spinal cord tissue within the protruding sac. Explanation: Myelomeningocele involves the herniation of the spinal cord, meninges, and cerebrospinal fluid through a vertebral defect. The presence of spinal cord tissue within the sac differentiates myelomeningocele from other forms of spina bifida, such as meningocele , in which only the meninges and cerebrospinal fluid are present in the sac without spinal cord involvement. Feature Meningocele Myelomeningocele Definition Protrusion of meninges through a vertebral defect (Option A) Protrusion of meninges and spinal cord through a vertebral defect (Option D) Sac contents Cerebrospinal fluid only. Cerebrospinal fluid and neural tissue. Neural involvement No neural elements in the sac (Option B) Spinal cord and/or nerve roots in the sac Skin coverage Often covered by skin Usually not covered by skin (open lesion) Neurological deficits Typically mild or absent Often severe Hydrocephalus risk Lower risk Higher risk Prognosis Generally better (Option C) Generally worse Surgical complexity Less complex More complex Long-term complications Fewer More frequent and severe Associated anomalies Less common More common

questions.question: Which of the following medications, when taken during pregnancy, is most strongly associated with an increased risk of myelomeningocele in the developing fetus?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Valproic acid Explanation: Valproic acid (anti-convulsant) is most strongly associated with an increased risk of myelomeningocele when taken during pregnancy. Metformin, amoxicillin, and levothyroxine are not specifically associated with significantly increased myelomeningocele risk (Options A, C, and D ruled out) Other drugs associated with increased risk of neural tube defects: Medication Primary Use Valproic acid Epilepsy, Bipolar disorder Carbamazepine Epilepsy, Trigeminal neuralgia Phenytoin Epilepsy Topiramate Epilepsy, Migraine prevention Methotrexate Cancer, Autoimmune diseases Trimethoprim Urinary tract infections Sulfasalazine Inflammatory bowel disease, Rheumatoid arthritis Mycophenolate mofetil Organ transplant rejection prevention Isotretinoin Severe acne Lithium Bipolar disorder Protective Factors Against Neural Tube Defects: Folic acid supplementation before and during early pregnancy can significantly reduce the risk of neural tube defects. Reference: https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/12790884/

questions.question: Which of the following is most commonly associated with Arnold-Chiari malformation type II?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Myelomeningocele Explanation: Arnold-Chiari malformation type II is almost always associated with myelomeningocele, a severe form of spina bifida where the spinal cord and meninges protrude through a defect in the spine. Feature Chiari I Chiari II Myelomeningocele Rare Almost always present Age at diagnosis Often adolescence/adulthood Usually, infancy or prenatal Syringomyelia Can occur More frequent Herniated structures Cerebellar tonsils only Cerebellar tonsils, vermis, brainstem Hydrocephalus Less common Very common Syringomyelia (Option A) is characterised by a fluid-filled cavity in the spinal cord and can occur in both type I and II Chiari malformations. It's more common in type II but not the most distinguishing feature. Adult-onset headaches (Option C) are more commonly associated with Chiari malformation type I, which is often diagnosed in adolescence or adulthood. Scoliosis (Option D): While this can occur in Chiari malformations, it's not the most distinctive or common feature of type II.

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT part of the classic triad of Dandy-Walker malformation?

options.A: Cystic dilatation of the fourth ventricle
options.B: Complete or partial agenesis of the cerebellar vermis

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Hydrocephalus Explanation: Hydrocephalus is not part of the classic triad of Dandy-Walker malformation. Dandy-Walker Malformation: Most frequent posterior fossa malformation and is due to the developmental failure of the fourth ventricle's roof. The classic triad consists of: Cystic dilatation of the fourth ventricle (Option A) Complete or partial agenesis of the cerebellar vermis (Option B) Enlarged posterior fossa with elevation of the tentorium cerebelli (Option C) Clinical Presentation: Macrocephaly (most common manifestation). Rapid head growth with prominent occiput. Possible long tract signs and cerebellar ataxia. Delayed motor/cognitive milestones. Associated Anomalies: CNS abnormalities in 70% of cases, including: Agenesis of posterior cerebellar vermis and corpus callosum Cortical dysplasia Polymicrogyria Diagnosis: MRI is the imaging modality of choice Treatment: Shunt placement for cystic cavity in patients with hydrocephalus.

questions.question: A 42-year-old male presents to the emergency department after an RTA, reporting a sudden, severe headache described as the "worst headache of his life," accompanied by nausea, vomiting, neck stiffness, and photophobia. A CT scan of the brain is provided. What is the most common cause of this condition?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Trauma Explanation: The patient's presentation with the "worst headache of his life," with neck stiffness and photophobia, along with CT findings showing an amorphous substance that fills the subarachnoid spaces around the brain, are suggestive of Subarachnoid haemorrhage. Trauma is the most common cause of SAH, followed by Rupture of Berry Aneurysm (Option B) Subarachnoid Hemorrhage: Causes: Most

questions.question: A 55-year-old patient presents with a sudden severe headache, brief loss of consciousness, nausea, and vomiting. Neurological examination shows decreased consciousness and mild focal deficits. A non-contrast CT scan of the head is provided. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Subdural Hematoma (SDH) Explanation: Given the clinical scenario and radiological findings showing a crescent-shaped blood collection that follows the brain's contours and crossing suture lines , the most probable diagnosis is Subdural Hematoma. Features Subdural Hematoma Extradural

questions.question: A 52-year-old male with a history of hypertension and smoking presents with sudden onset of nausea, vomiting, and confusion. On examination, he has a decreased level of consciousness and neck stiffness. A non-contrast CT scan reveals subarachnoid haemorrhage. Which of the following statements about Berry aneurysms is not true?

options.A: Associated with connective tissue disorders like Marfan's syndrome.
options.B: Absence of smooth muscle and intimal elastic lamina.
options.C: Most commonly seen at the bifurcation of the vertebrobasilar arteries.

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Most commonly seen at the bifurcation of the vertebrobasilar arteries. of Willis, such as the junction of the anterior cerebral and anterior communicating artery , not at the bifurcation of the vertebrobasilar arteries. It is the most common type of intracranial aneurysm. Saccular & typically located in the anterior circulation of the Circle of Willis. Common Sites: Junction of Anterior Communicating and Anterior Cerebral Artery (Most Common) > Bifurcation of MCA (2nd Most Common) > Junction of PCA and Internal Carotid Artery > Intracranial Carotid Bifurcation > Bifurcation of Vertebrobasilar (Option C) Structural Features: Absence of Smooth Muscle and Intimal Elastic Lamina (Option B) Wall Composition: Thickened, hyalinised intima Clinical Presentation: Ruptured Berry Aneurysm: Can cause subarachnoid haemorrhage (SAH) or intracerebral haemorrhage and the most common rupture site is the dome or apex. Unruptured Berry Aneurysm: Usually asymptomatic and often discovered incidentally. (Option D) Treatment: Endovascular Coil Occlusion: Preferred method. Surgical Clipping: Used if endovascular methods are unsuitable. Complications: Rebleeding Hydrocephalus : Managed with an external ventricular drain. Vasospasm : Treated with hypervolemia, induced hypertension, and medication. Conditions Associated with Berry Aneurysms: Fibromuscular Dysplasia (FMD) Marfan’s Syndrome (Option A) Ehlers-Danlos Syndrome Coarctation of aorta Autosomal dominant Polycystic Kidney disease

questions.question: A 45-year-old man with a recent dental infection presents with persistent headaches, fever, and confusion. He exhibits focal neurological deficits and seizures. The radiological findings are provided. Given his clinical presentation and imaging, what is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?

options.A: Initiate IV antibiotics and immediate surgical drainage
options.B: Start oral antibiotics and monitor with CT every 48 hours
options.C: Administer high-dose corticosteroids and supportive care
options.D: Begin antiepileptic medications and refer for op follow-up.

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Initiate IV antibiotics and immediate surgical drainage Explanation: Given the history of a recent dental infection, along with imaging showing a ring-enhancing lesion in the frontal lobe and symptoms of fever, confusion, and seizures, the most likely diagnosis is a Brain abscess. questions.question: A 58-year-old patient presents with a significant right-sided brain tumour. During the neurological examination, the patient exhibits left-sided weakness. Which of the following best accounts for this presentation?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Kernohan notch phenomenon Explanation: Kernohan's notch phenomenon involves the compression of the contralateral cerebral peduncle due to a brain mass effect, leading to motor deficits on the opposite side. Mechanism: Cerebral Peduncle Compression: A brain mass, often associated with transtentorial or uncal herniation, exerts pressure on the contralateral (opposite side) cerebral peduncle. Tentorium Interaction: This compression happens against the free edge of the tentorium cerebelli, creating an indentation or "notch" in the cerebral peduncle. Clinical Presentation: Contralateral Hemiparesis: Due to damage to motor pathways in the contralateral cerebral peduncle. Ipsilateral Ocular Symptoms: If the herniation affects the oculomotor nerve (cranial nerve III) on the same side as the mass, it may lead to ipsilateral (same side) oculomotor nerve palsy. Brown-Sequard Syndrome (Option B) involves damage to one side of the spinal cord, leading to specific patterns of sensory and motor deficits which don’t match the brain tumor scenario. Tullio Phenomenon (Option C) is associated with inner ear disorders causing dizziness and hearing problems, and it is not relevant to motor deficits from a brain tumor. Uhthoff's Phenomenon (Option D) involves the worsening of neurological symptoms with heat in conditions like multiple sclerosis, which is not related to a brain tumor's mass effect.

questions.question: A 62-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after a fall from a ladder. He has a GCS score of 9 (E2V3M4), and his right pupil is dilated and nonreactive. The CT scan shows a large right-sided subdural hematoma with a significant midline shift to the left. BP: 180/100 mmHg, HR: 52 beats/minute with irregular breathing patterns. Which type of brain herniation is most likely occurring in this patient?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Uncal herniation Explanation: The patient is most likely experiencing uncal herniation based on the following findings: Large Right-Sided Subdural Hematoma: Creates a space-occupying lesion, leading to significant mass effect. Significant Midline Shift to the Left : Indicates severe displacement of brain structures. Dilated and Nonreactive Right Pupil: A classic sign of uncal herniation due to oculomotor nerve compression. Decreased Level of Consciousness (GCS 9): Resulting from brainstem compression. Signs of Cushing's Triad: I ncluding hypertension, bradycardia, and irregular breathing, indicative of increased intracranial pressure. Uncal herniation occurs when the medial temporal lobe (uncus) is displaced downward through the tentorial notch, compressing the ipsilateral oculomotor nerve and brainstem . Subfalcine herniation(Option A) typically causes contralateral leg weakness but not pupillary changes. Tonsillar herniation(Option B) primarily affects the lower brainstem and cervical spinal cord. Upward transtentorial herniation(Option C) is rare and usually occurs with infratentorial lesions.

questions.question: A 62-year-old man undergoes emergent decompressive craniectomy for a large right hemispheric infarct with significant mass effect. Post-surgery, he remains comatose and, six hours later, develops pinpoint pupils and irregular breathing. A stat CT scan shows resolution of the midline shift but reveals new bilateral hyperdense lesions in the midbrain. What is the most likely explanation for these new CT findings?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Duret hemorrhage Explanation: The new CT findings are most consistent with Duret haemorrhage , characterised by small, linear or flame-shaped haemorrhages primarily in the midbrain and upper pons. It is typically caused by the rapid displacement of the brainstem, which can occur due to significant mass effects or sudden changes in intracranial pressure, such as those seen after decompressive surgery. This results from stretching and tearing the perforating branches of the basilar artery. Clinically present with persistent coma, pinpoint pupils, and irregular breathing suggest brainstem dysfunction, suggesting brainstem dysfunction. Contrast extravasation (Option A) would be unusual without recent contrast administration and typically doesn't present with bilateral midbrain lesions. Hemorrhagic transformation of infarct (Option B) : While possible, this would typically occur in the area of the original infarct (right hemisphere), not in the midbrain. Hypertensive microbleeds (Option D) usually occur over time and are more commonly found in other areas of the brain, not specifically bilateral in the midbrain. Reference: Sabiston’s Textbook of Surgery, 21st edition, page 1885
